TopicTitle: A potential space battle system for KSP

Articles.Content:
So I just watched the series 1 conclusion in macey deans KSP series.

This was really impressive for me, and I was wondering if we could develop his battle sytem into something that could be used for other engagements.

At about 8:10, the rules of engagement can be seen. I'd love to use these rules for some other battle, and even organise them over the forums, but first I feel some discrepancies need to be cleared up.

1. There should be a minimum distance away from every other ship a craft can stray during its turn. This would be to stop people splitting the battle up unfairly.

2. There needs to be a defined way to classify ships as a fighter, frigate, or capital ship. Maybe tonnage or dimensions?

3. There should be a way of quantifying the strength of each ship so that engagements can be fair.

Let me know what you think.
I like the idea, except I think rule #3 is unnecessary, whoever builds the better ship should have the advantage just as they would irl.
KSP is a great game because it offers you a lot of challenge without any violence.

But...why? There will be no aliens in this game. Multiplayer is waaaaay away according to devs. So what? First you have to laboriously put two complicated, part heavy ships in space. Then you have to match their trajectories so fight is possible at all. And then you just destroy your own work - all the while knowing everything about their relative positions, capabilities etc. No surprise, no fog-of-war...where is excitement in all this mirror-fighting? Macey Dean at least does it for the purpose of movie making. Does this game lacks difficulty and challenge for you? Is it for role-playing? But then it's like a RPG session where you are both GM and sole player - again no surprise and excitement since you automatically know all and controll all.

O look, this again

It's a SINGLE PLAYER GAME

Make your own rules, shoot at ships with wack a kerbal, instal a mod, I don't give a hoot. But stop spewing your battlefield fanboyism over here

could never play a random game or something, as people would probably just abuse quick save to get the perfect shots in, and do silly things like approacing to 20m over the course of 45minutes careful maneuvering.

Macey and suestra here played it fair, and for the camera, (although I really disagree with the suiciding hanlan, I think it spoiled something) macey even taking shots from way out at 600+ metres when he could have come right up to the damn ship and fired point blank at whatever weak spot he wanted, and no quickloads when things didn`t go quite to plan.

Playing with a friend of yours.. sure why not, but abuse would be impenetrable in any sort of randomly shared game

People are probably better off playing an online space combat game, and leaving KSP free of this stuff, other than for cinematic purposes

One thing that gets overlooked in these combat scenarios is how crushingly, mind-numbingly boring combat bound by Newtonian physics really would be. You spend hours trying to intercept your opponent (assuming he's not actively avoiding you, which would be ridiculously simple as long as his engines are halfway functional), you get one chance per intercept to blast him as you go whizzing by so you don't take a beating as well, wash, rinse, repeat. Yawn.

Not trying to be a party pooper, but reality (or quasi-realism with a Kerbal chaser in this case) is a lot duller than Star Wars.

While I'm not big on pitting Kerbal vs. Kerbal, if he wants to put these up Just For Fun, don't flame the guy. There's already weapon mods and armed spaceships-
